channel.title: Reflection
channel.description: is reflection a vaiable way to grab values from the client? http://rafb.net/paste/results/l3IxF810.html

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

[quote=“ruler, post:20, topic:5415”]NOURLOL, its a trap!

Jagex does do
field.getModifiers();
and making everything public will be dectable.

What i advise:
Use reflection or
edit the reflection api and have getModifiers() return the modifiers from a set of untouched class you loaded from the offical runescape.com

I have backed off all my rt.jar edits now that you showed me the applet stub solution.

If you are going to edit the rt.jar let me show how:
java -Xbootclasspath/a:%~dp0impsoft.jar Main;

Watch out tho they have this warning:
“Note: Applications that use this option for the purpose of overriding a class in rt.jar should not be deployed as doing so would contravene the Java 2 Runtime Environment binary code license.”

I hope those who use my strategy credit hehe.[/quote]

There was an appletStub solution was in ARGA’s source when it was released, its just slightly diffrent simply because we did our own before that one was released and dont use regex’s. :).

Ye my opinion is. Bytecode is a much better option.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @NOURLOL NOURLOL
item.description:
@NOURLOL wrote:

I’ve found that field access isn’t a problem for me, all of the stuff I need to access, for the most part seems to be public, as it’s usually accessed from other classes.
On a side note, I’ve got a leet & fully automagical pattern=>accessorclass generator thing going, lol:

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

I change them when I need access, yes. I dont even check to see if they are even public first, I just do it, then work with the object, then set it back to whatever it was to begin with.

Its slight slower during runtime, but its never dealt with again… I dont ever know the name of whats being passed in, I dont care what the name is, I care about the bot being able to do what its supposed to do, and it can.

No deobs, no looking/changing at anything after a update, etc… (Every now and then something breaks, and needs to be changed, but its not any methods that deal with this, or that work with the varialbes… only methods to locate the variables in the first place ever need to be changed, if there is a change needed…)

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

Nerice:

Dude, forget reflection, it sucks ass, and its much slower than BCEL.

so you use bcel and on/off the field/class access levels everytime you need to get a refrence to a object/primative?
so a setpermission is faster in bcel than in reflection?

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

Dude, forget reflection, it sucks ass, and its much slower than BCEL.

Reflection is powerful, but once I got to looking at BCEL, reflection sucks… totally sucks. Its slower, not as powerful as BCEL, and much messier to deal with.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“Nerice, post:22, topic:5415”]Ruler, nohting says you cant change the modifiers, do what you need to do and put the modifiers back to the way they was right after your done…

Not even a pain to do, method that gets the object passed in, stores the access in a variable, and changes it to what you need. Next is the call to your method you need to work with it, next is the call to a different method that just puts the permissions back to what was stored in the varilable in the first method.

First and last method never changes…[/quote]
sounds like reflection

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

Ruler, nohting says you cant change the modifiers, do what you need to do and put the modifiers back to the way they was right after your done…

Not even a pain to do, method that gets the object passed in, stores the access in a variable, and changes it to what you need. Next is the call to your method you need to work with it, next is the call to a different method that just puts the permissions back to what was stored in the varilable in the first method.

First and last method never changes…

Let stuff take the microseconds longer during runtime that it takes to do it, and the the freaking base java classes alone.

Read full topic

item.description:
@ruler wrote:

NOURLOL, its a trap!

Jagex does do
field.getModifiers();
and making everything public will be dectable.

What i advise:
Use reflection or
edit the reflection api and have getModifiers() return the modifiers from a set of untouched class you loaded from the offical runescape.com

I have backed off all my rt.jar edits now that you showed me the applet stub solution.

If you are going to edit the rt.jar let me show how:
java -Xbootclasspath/a:%~dp0impsoft.jar Main;

Watch out tho they have this warning:
“Note: Applications that use this option for the purpose of overriding a class in rt.jar should not be deployed as doing so would contravene the Java 2 Runtime Environment binary code license.”

I hope those who use my strategy credit hehe.

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @NOURLOL NOURLOL
item.description:
@NOURLOL wrote:

Nerice is right, there is almost no point using reflection.
I’ve written a nice little application that runs my transforms/bcel patterns for me, and generates a class of basically accessor methods.

Running Transform: CreationTransform Creating the client function class ... Running Transform: MouseListenerTransform MouseWrapper, type=kd, instance=jc.dc Running Transform: SignlinkTransform First signlink object = ra.ld Second signlink object = gd.K Running Transform: GenericPatternTransform getActionData1 => int[] kb.c getDataRow => int le.db getActionData2 => int[] q.B getActionData3 => int[] uc.x getActionData4 => int[] fd.d getNpcArray => hd[] td.ab getByteGroundArray => byte[][][] rb.q getPlane => int na.k getPlayerArray => ra[] nd.Fb myPlayer => ra m.kc getModelIntArray1 => int[] de.ec getYCameraCurve => int qe.B getModelIntArray2 => int[] de.hc Running Transform: CleanupTransform Cleaning up ... Finished running transforms, dumping classes
Generated: (jad decompiles some of it improperly, i.e getMouseWrapperClass shite)

[code]// Decompiled by Jad v1.5.8f. Copyright 2001 Pavel Kouznetsov.
// Jad home page: http://www.kpdus.com/jad.html
// Decompiler options: packimports(3)
// Source File Name: ClientFunctionsTemplate.java

public class ClientFunctions
{

public ClientFunctions()
{
}

public static void main(String args1[])
{
}

public static Class getMouseWrapperClass()
{
    return kd;
}

public static kd getMouseWrapperObject()
{
    return jc.dc;
}

public static jb getFirstSignlinkRunner()
{
    return ra.ld;
}

public static void setFirstSignlinkRunner(jb arg0)
{
    ra.ld = arg0;
}

public static jb getSecondSignlinkRunner()
{
    return gd.K;
}

public static void setSecondSignlinkRunner(jb arg0)
{
    gd.K = arg0;
}

public static int[] getActionData1()
{
    return kb.c;
}

public static int getDataRow()
{
    return le.db;
}

public static int[] getActionData2()
{
    return q.B;
}

public static int[] getActionData3()
{
    return uc.x;
}

public static int[] getActionData4()
{
    return fd.d;
}

public static hd[] getNpcArray()
{
    return td.ab;
}

public static byte[][][] getByteGroundArray()
{
    return rb.q;
}

public static int getPlane()
{
    return na.k;
}

public static ra[] getPlayerArray()
{
    return nd.Fb;
}

public static ra myPlayer()
{
    return m.kc;
}

public static int[] getModelIntArray1()
{
    return de.ec;
}

public static int getYCameraCurve()
{
    return qe.B;
}

public static int[] getModelIntArray2()
{
    return de.hc;
}

public static client clientInstance;

}[/code]

And I just use that from my bot. Problem of reflection is gone (maybe except field access, shit!)

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

Use bytecode, its much better than reflection. Can write reusable code that never changes, even when Jagex updates etc…

Maybe there is a reason you want to know the name of the variable yourself, but for me I could care less, the bot knows.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

speed difference is about 10 to 1 when using invoke() instead of direct calls. I don;t knwo the difference for getField() compared to direct.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

To use the AccessibleObject class, you would need the class object right? How to get it without the jvm bitching about cross referencing? I found a library that can load them and set dependencies - its called JPF, although haven't implemented it yet.

I don’t know exactly how to answer your question. I’ll answer both questions you could have possibly meant to ask. The ‘class object’ is available as soon as the system or custom classloader loads the class in question and is available by simply accessing the class static variable. ie. a.class. The other possible meaning was instance of that class which would pose a different problem. Yes, you would need access to that instance object in order to reflect on it only if it is a nonstatic member. This means that for nonstatic members, it would be a bit tough.

However, if the member was static, piece of cake; "null"s the parameter.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @RLN RLN
item.description:
@RLN wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:12, topic:5415”][quote author=pplsuqbawlz link=topic=7154.msg75325#msg75325 date=1153406352]
reflection can grab variables at any time i believe so long as theyre package/public access
[/quote]

On the surface, that’s correct. If you were looking to access private members all you have to do is call the setAccessible method on the field/method instance. I would personally never use this because it would be frightfully slow and cumbersome.

Nevertheless, there it is.

BTW, nice post on the hashCode there pplsuq… can’t imagine where you got that idea… :P[/quote]To use the AccessibleObject class, you would need the class object right? How to get it without the jvm bitching about cross referencing? I found a library that can load them and set dependencies - its called JPF, although haven’t implemented it yet.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

pplsuqbawlz:

reflection can grab variables at any time i believe so long as theyre package/public access

On the surface, that’s correct. If you were looking to access private members all you have to do is call the setAccessible method on the field/method instance. I would personally never use this because it would be frightfully slow and cumbersome.

Nevertheless, there it is.

BTW, nice post on the hashCode there pplsuq… can’t imagine where you got that idea…

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

I can get the values no matter if they are in a private or static. I can also go tru their arrays.

I wrote a quick outputter that wrote out every varible, but i think i have alot of repeats, it was about 800,000 lines and that is without expanding arrays. So i will need to look to filter them.
[S reflection3] private int loader.a = 503
[S reflection3] private boolean loader.b = false
[S reflection3] private int loader.c = 765
[S reflection3] private static int client.pa.qb.sa.db.fe.nb.ua.r.hc = 0
[S reflection3] static int client.pa.qb.sa.db.fe.nb.ua.r.ac = -5
[S reflection3] static int[][] loader.client.ud.jc.ea.nb.a = null
[S reflection3] public hc loader.ae.i = null[br][size=1]Posted at: July 20, 2006, 02:38:26 PM[/size][hr][quote=“pplsuqbawlz, post:6, topic:5415”]reflection can grab variables at any time i believe so long as theyre package/public access[/quote]
private instance varibles are also accessible

I don’t recommend using reflection to .invoke it is almsot 10 times more expensive than direct invocation.

Read full topic
